column2: @irlfede @Commsor very true

Congrats @Commsor on the recent round, exciting to see more and more investment going into the community space. 

https://t.co/CBrOj9u9aW

To be a great community builder you have to shift your mindset from creating content that people connect with to creating content that connects people to each other.

It‚Äôs subtle, but powerful. 

Always ask, ‚ÄúHow will this content help our members connect to each other?‚Äù
@rosiesherry @mattmecham @hlashbrooke do contributors get any of that profit?

@Historian they're both models for creating products/value, no?

i've seen people say "why launch a DAO? just make it open source"

@mattmecham is that true?

the goal of most DAOs is to build things that make the world better

@mattmecham @rosiesherry @hlashbrooke but altruism doesn't pay the bills in a capitalist system

our altruism is capped
@Shanahasatwitr #fridayfunday

Types of community posts:

- conversation starter: open ended question
- support: question with specific answers
- collections: ask for links/resources/promotions
- connection: help members find commonalities
- gossip: share trending news / information 

What are some others?
@andy4edu kids are a cheat code for transitioning to life mode

How I transition my mind from work to life mode when WFH:

1. Sight: change lighting, go outside, read book, no screens
2. Smell: light a candle/incense
3. Touch: stretch, take walk, touch grass
4. Sound: switch music, use a singing bowl
5. Taste: make herbal tea, have a treat
@mhall119 @cosmicblend how I'm thinking about it is that they're both contribution models
@ianhunter as I understand it (which is not very much) - part of the point of open source is that no one owns it. In web3, members own it.
@gcheung28 glad to hear that part resonated!

@cosmicblend if you were to launch a project and were looking for contributors and a contributor model, would you not consider open source and a DAO two different options?

(genuinely asking... I don't know the answer)
@simon_tomes i agree - though I see it changing already
@cult_leader_en the reasoning I've heard for not doing this is that it makes the token a security
@rosiesherry @TheGrandWorld and @DinnerPartiers come to mind

I would LOVE to read a deep dive on what the two models can learn from each other, similar to what @austinrobey_ wrote up for Co-ops and DAOs

https://t.co/EmAZHo4PWj

What are the pros/cons of open-source vs web3?

Has anyone written up a good comparison of the two models?
@simon_tomes I believe that culture will change

@hlashbrooke @mattmecham Of course, but there's a line where the amount of time and effort someone puts into a project deserves compensation, right?

And a contributor can only contribute to extent they're able to dedicate that time without compensation, something a lot of people can't do.

@charlierward @austinrobey_ they have to be for-profit so they don't qualify for a lot of grants that are only made for non-profits

and they don't appeal to VCs because they aren't built for an exit or an IPO and are intentionally build to be owned by members

RT @Meetup: Life is full of choices, how you make those decisions dictates your path. 
Listen to @DavidSpinks and @DavidMeirSiegel discuss‚Ä¶

@mhall119 @hlashbrooke ah i thought it was - thanks for clarifying

does the same not hold true for open source projects that are acquired?

@hlashbrooke @mhall119 But the company is still determining the decisions that the members can make, the company can give and take away ownership any time, and the members don't have mechanisms to decide collectively.
@TreyLockerbie @_shahedk @jmj @SahilBloom @HarryStebbings we need answers @SahilBloom

@hlashbrooke Even rewards don't translate to the same value as ownership though, and decision-making power is limited.

When Microsoft bought Github for example, the contributors didn't have a say in that decision, and didn't get any of the $7.5 billion paid, right?
@hlashbrooke sounds like we need to find some time for a call (=

@hlashbrooke Interesting...I have some noob questions about open source...

Does open source provide any mechanisms for compensating contributors?

How are decisions made in open source projects?

Is it true that open source has a challenge keeping contributors engaged?

@charlierward both still require members to buy in, and don't have a mechanism for rewarding contributions

co-ops have been the best option to date, but as i'm learning from @austinrobey_, funding co-ops is really difficult

In web2, the best we can do is give community members a "sense of ownership".

The ability to give community members *literal* ownership is one of the things that draws me most to web3.

@hey_bernie @austinrobey_ i think we're going to see a lot of innovation and improvements in how DAOs are run, and once some of these systems are built, a lot of community-minded builders are going to be very drawn to this model

Just talked to @austinrobey_ about DAOs and co-ops for an hour on MoC and it feels like my brain is going to explode. 

Can't wait to share this episode with you all.

@drewmeyers what does it require? curious how you define it / where you draw the line

i like to think about under what circumstances could we consider ourselves a "global community"
@drewmeyers why not?

Community is one of the most broadly defined words in the dictionary.

It can mean anything from "family" to "every person in the world."

So before you start building "community", take the time to get more specific about what it is you actually want to build.
@francjp happy to hear it resonates, thanks for sharing Francisco
@avinashraghava glad to hear it resonated

@tina_yip people best not be throwing away my swagger
@Keivansamani *unless your community is PhD students

Swag won't convince anyone to love your brand. They'll probably throw it away.

But the people who already love your brand will love your swag and rep it proudly.

Lesson: Only send swag to people who already love your brand.

@Bluegirlpdx @daniellexo I personally love using SOC as more of a brainstorming and planning tool to identify ways to improve your community, rather than using SOCi as an analytical tool.

But that's just me.

@Bluegirlpdx @daniellexo SOCi is a really valuable tool. It provides a thorough analysis. My challenge with it is that it's a very complex survey to run and to analyze, and feels a bit more academic, missing some more practical questions and applications we focus on in our survey.

@ZainaHmoud you do have to be mindful of survey fatigue

make sure to track how many surveys members are getting and prioritize gathering insights that are going to be most impactful for them

@Tom_Voltz1 @iambethmcintyre It gives us benchmarks on how members of these groups are experiencing the community. If members of specific groups are having a negative experience in the community, it helps keep us accountable to fixing those issues, and making the community more inclusive.
@markgrimes LOVE this

Humans need a variety of community. 

Small and large
Intimate and passive 
Financial and social
Online and offline 
Adventurous and grounding
Synchronous and asynchronous
Anonymous and transparent 

No one community can provide us with the breadth of connection we crave.
